is satisfied at any time for the position Ui and the velocity iii of this 4-dimensional motion.  We shall not discuss here the feasibility of such a construction but proceed directl }^ to the differential equations of the motion in R ^, Afterwards it can be verified that our goal has been reached. 
In order to start this line of approach we regard the parameters iii as generalized coordinates for the motion of the particle m in the sense of Lagrangian mechanics.  Their relation to the ordinary coordinates Xk is given by ( 6 ). There is no contradiction in introducing 4 Lagrangian coordinates for this motion of 3 degrees of freedom,  since the Ui must satisfy the non-holonomic relation ( 23 ). The velocity r of m is given by formula ( 13 ) :

Next we have to compute the generalized forces Qi corresponding to the generalized coordinates Ui.  They are defined by the requirement that the work done by the forces remains invariant under the transformation :
